title: Is there, or can there ever be, a star that is large enough to contain our entire solar system? - Quora

response.answer_text: The largest diameter star known to exist is VY Canis Majoris VY Canis Majoris - Wikipedia If the Sun were replaced with this star then all the planets up to and including Jupiter would be engulfed by it. This star is almost at the limit of how large a star can be (explained in a further wiki article which the above links to), so no, there can’t be a single star large enough to contain the entire solar system.

VY Canis Major is the largest we’ve found so far and would be large enough to encompass Saturn (probably). So no, not even close to the whole solar system seeing as there appears to be at least one other large planet outside the Kuiper belt which we haven’t even identified yet, but if true would mean that the orbit of Saturn is only about a half of the solar system (or less). This doesn’t mean there absolutely couldn’t be a bigger star, just we haven’t found it yet. Interestingly, a photon would take about 6 hours to travel around VY Canis Major, whereas for our sun it’s only about 15 seconds. It is BIG!
